citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There is a female dromedary camel in an enclosure with three other dromedary camels. This female camel is very thin.
The ribs of the camel can be observed through the hair coat. The licensee stated that the last time a veterinarian had
examined this camel due to weight loss was November 5, 2023. Per the licensee blood work was completed along with a
urinalysis and fecal examination. Per the licensee the veterinarian recommended an injection of B12 and selenium. The
licensee stated that the camel had gained some weight after the injection but has since lost weight again. The licensee
has not called the veterinarian to follow up since the camel has lost weight again.
Failing to conduct daily observations or maintaining frequent and direct communication with the attending veterinarian
concerning any veterinary issue observed by the licensee may result in discomfort or animals suffering due to an injury or
disease without prompt veterinary treatment.
Each exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include daily observation of all
animals to assess their health and well-being; Provided, however, that daily observation of animals may be accomplished
by someone other than the attending veterinarian; and Provided, further, that a mechanism of direct and frequent
communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being
is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. Animals that have been observed to have a veterinary issue must be
communicated to the attending veterinarian for appropriate diagnosis and treatment.

The licensee stated that a young, male llama was sold at auction over the previous weekend. There is no record of this
sale.
Every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following
information concerning animals other than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or
otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise
disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her
possession or under his or her control. Records of animal acquisition and disposition are required to trace and track
animals in the event of an animal disease outbreak, and to ensure all individuals involved have a valid USDA license if a
license is required.
Records must be kept of all animal acquisitions and dispositions.
Corrected at time of inspection

There is a very large pile of straw and feces, approximately 10 feet by 10 feet and 3 feet tall right next to the primary
enclosure for the four sheep. The licensee had cleaned out the sheep and alpaca enclosure in February and left the pile
in place.
Failing to appropriately remove or dispose of waste such as animal and food wastes, or bedding can harbor disease and
attract pests like flies which may bite or cause discomfort from flying around their eyes and faces.
Provision shall be made for the removal and disposal of animal and food wastes, bedding, dead animals, trash and
debris. Disposal facilities shall be so provided and operated as to minimize vermin infestation, odors, and disease
hazards. The disposal facilities and any disposal of animal and food wastes, bedding, dead animals, trash, and debris
shall comply with applicable Federal, State, and local laws and regulations relating to pollution control or the protection of
the environment.

The sheltered area of the primary enclosure housing four dromedary camels has excessive feces in it. The manure pack
of straw and feces measures approximately 12 inches. The legs and bellies of the camels show dark debris on them,
consistent with soiling from the manure accumulation.
Accumulations of feces that come into contact with the skin may cause skin irritation, sores and infection.
Excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals
contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. When enclosures are cleaned by hosing or
flushing, adequate measures shall be taken to protect the animals confined in such enclosures from being directly
sprayed with the stream of water or wetted involuntarily.

There are rat holes noted under and around the primary enclosure for the two African Crested porcupines and the two
capybaras. The licensee stated they have tried rat traps but it hasn’t been effective.
Pests can harbor diseases that are transmitted directy to the animals or may contaminate feed or water which could make
the animals sick.
A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall be
established and maintained. This requirement includes but, is not limited to, an effective method to control rats as pests .
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
KURT HAMMEL, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
